ud3.2:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud3.2:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Nanda, the Buddha’s paternal cousin, informed several mendicants:
ud3.2:1.5: I am unable to keep up the spiritual life. I shall  resign the training and return to a lesser life.”
ud3.2:2.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
ud3.2:3.1: So the Buddha addressed a certain monk,
ud3.2:3.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Nanda that
ud3.2:3.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Nanda and said to him,
ud3.2:4.1: “Yes, reverend,” Nanda replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
ud3.2:5.1: “Is it really true, Nanda, that you informed several mendicants that
ud3.2:5.2: you are unable to keep up the spiritual life; that you shall resign the training and return to a lesser life?”
ud3.2:6.1: “But why are you so dissatisfied with the spiritual life?”
ud3.2:6.2: “As I left my house, sir, the finest lady of the Sakyan land, her hair half-combed, glanced at me and said,
ud3.2:6.4: Recalling that, I am dissatisfied and shall resign the training.”
ud3.2:7.1: Then the Buddha took Nanda by the arm and, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the Thirty-Three.
ud3.2:8.1: Now at that time five hundred nymphs with feet as pink as pigeons’ feet had come to attend to Sakka, the lord of gods.
